subject: Use (# of CPUs) glance workers by default

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Looks like workers is hard-coded to 1 in glance-api.conf under glance/etc:

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/glance/tree/etc/glance-api.conf#n63

Patch Set 1:

Hi Matt,

Will this change also affect the number of glance-registry workers if a user is not explicitly specifying the number of registry workers in glance-registry.conf?

Patch Set 1:

Stuart, there is no workers setting in glance-registry.conf.

Patch Set 1:

Sounds like I should also sync up lockutils in the dependent oslo sync since I'm hitting deadlocks in the glance functional tests, and lockutils is quite out of date in glance (last updated on 1/2/14).

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hi Matt,

The wsgi code is common to the API and the Registry, so back when I added the multi-process/workers code I got two for the price of one :-)

There does seem to be a gap in the documentation -- I don't see any mention of workers w.r.t the registry. I've put this bug in for that:

 https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1334711

and will submit a doc patch.

If you can update your commit message to reflect the registry impact that would be great -- thanks!

Patch Set 1:

@Stuart, sure, I'll do that.

Patch Set 1:

I probably actually need to make I6795c6e22268bb3fb67331edc7af641aefa904cc a dependency of this so I can change the conf file to set workers=None in glance-registry.conf.

Patch Set 1:

Thanks Matt.

Looking forward to this landing.

Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Any ideas on why these errors are occurring in the unit tests? Doesn't seem like the patch would introduce an error...

Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I'm waiting for this to fix the check queue:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/102915/

Then I'm going to recheck https://review.openstack.org/#/c/91047/ until that merges, so I can redo my dependency oslo-sync and pull in the latest lockutils (already have that sitting locally).

As for why this hangs in the functional tests, I really have no idea at this point.  I've tried setting workers=1 in the functional tests (rather than 0 which creates the thread pool rather than the process), that didn't help.  I've tried commented out the workers option in the config created for the functional tests but that didn't help.  When the functional tests appear to be hanging, I grep the glance processes and get this:

https://gist.github.com/mriedem/329d091b03b39cf136fe

I've checked the tox.ini and .testr.conf setup for glance and compared to other projects and don't see anything differently for how it runs the tests and uses lockutils.

So I'm at a loss for the time being.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

Patch Set 4:

First -- a big thanks to Zhi Yan Liu for his great test related comments.

This is really good functionality -- especially from a TripleO perspective.

I've one query: Do folks feel that it would be more consistent for the API and registry to have the same default behaviour? (Before this change they both defaulted to '1' -- the API explicitly and the registry implicitly.)

I'd like to see both default to the number of processors -- what does anyone else think?

Patch Set 4:

+1 for Stuarts proposal for extending this to registry as well.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

Hi Matt,

Now I've actually looked at the code :-)

Based on this comment:

UpgradeImpact: There is no upgrade impact to glance-api workers
           since glance-api.conf previously hard-coded the workers
           value to 1 so anyone upgrading to tihs will still get
           whatever value was set in glance-api.conf prior to
           this change.

I thought that the default api workers value was unchanged, but I see it's been
removed.

I think this comment:

 So anyone upgrading to this change that does not have workers specified in glance-registry.conf will now be running multiple workers by default

applies equally to api workers.

I'm going to +2 anyway in case I'm being too pedantic :-) but if you think the relevant section of the commit message is worth rewording, go for it!

Patch Set 4:

@Stuart, besides the typo in the commit message (s/tihs/this), I think it's correct.

Currently glance-api.conf has workers=1, so that's the default if I setup a fresh glance install today.  In Icehouse, (before your recent change really), glance-registry.conf didn't have an entry for workers so it would default to whatever was in the wsgi code, which was 1 (before this change).  That's because of the option definition in wsgi.py:

cfg.IntOpt('workers', default=1

With my change here, that's gone so a fresh install is going to get whatever the default in wsgi.py is if they don't have workers specified explicitly in either of the config files.

My point on the UpgradeImpact is if I'm upgrading from an Icehouse installation where I just took the defaults and didn't change anything, and restart the glance services, glance-api will still have 1 worker (because workers=1 in glance-api.conf in Icehouse), but they will go from 1 to $nproc registry workers in Juno with this change.

Anyone doing a fresh Juno install will get $nproc workers by default for each service.

Am I missing anything here?  Does this clarify it and if so, is there anything here I should updating the commit message?

Patch Set 4:

Thanks Matt.

> Am I missing anything here?

Potentially just the corner case for those users who have no entry at all for 'workers' in glance-api.conf (ie they are not using the default config file and have not explicitly set any value). When those users upgrade there will be an api impact.
Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1
